title: 112_hr1815
content: The Act may be cited as the "Lena Horne Recognition Act". Lena Horne, born in 1917 in Brooklyn, New York, started her career as a dancer at the Cotton Club at 16. She became one of the first African-American women to perform with an all-White band in 1940. Despite her talent, she faced racial limitations in acting roles. Lena Horne was the first Black artist to sign a long-term contract with MGM. Lena Horne faced racial limitations in acting roles due to her race, with scenes of her singing often being cut in the South. Despite this, she dazzled in films like Cabin in the Sky and Stormy Weather. During World War II, she toured with the USO, refusing to perform for segregated audiences or in front of German prisoners of war. During McCarthyism in the 1950s, Lena Horne was blacklisted for 7 years due to her civil rights activism. Despite discrimination, her career flourished, recording a successful album in 1957. She rose to international stardom, performing with renowned artists and starring in musical and television specials. Lena Horne used her fame to advocate for civil rights and equality, participating in the March on Washington in 1963 and working with various organizations. She continued to entertain audiences of all backgrounds through the end of the 20th century. Lena Horne was a renowned entertainer and activist who appeared on various television shows and in the film adaption of The Wiz. In 1981, she captivated audiences with her one-woman Broadway show, Lena Horne: The Lady and Her Music, earning her a special Tony and two Grammy awards. Halle Berry recognized Horne's influence when she became the first Black woman to win an Oscar for Best Actress in 2002. Horne passed away in 2010 at the age of 92. Lena Horne, an entertainer, activist, and mother, used her beauty, talent, and intelligence to fight racial discrimination and rise to international stardom. She entertained people from all walks of life for over 60 years, breaking barriers for future generations. Congress authorizes the posthumous presentation of a gold medal to Lena Horne for her achievements in American culture and the civil rights movement. The medal will be designed and struck by the Secretary of the Treasury. Duplicate medals may also be created. The Secretary is authorized to create duplicate bronze medals of the gold medal, sell them at a price to cover costs. The medals are considered national medals and numismatic items. Proceeds from sales can be used as authorized. SEC. 6. AUTHORITY TO USE FUND AMOUNTS; PROCEEDS OF SALE. The United States Mint Public Enterprise Fund is authorized to cover costs of medals struck under this Act. Proceeds from the sale of duplicate bronze medals will be deposited into the Fund.
